block.p: Sales at Cisco Systems Increase 61% in Quarter Cisco Systems reported a 61 percent gain in sales for its fiscal fourth quarter, as the company continued to be the leading supplier of the necessary hardware for the Internet.
Excluding acquisition-related charges, Cisco's earnings exceeded Wall Street analysts' estimates by a penny a share. [Page C6.]

Speculation on Firestone Tire Recall Bridgestone said it would hold a news conference today in Washington amid speculation that it is preparing to recall millions of Firestone tires after dozens of safety complaints and at least 21 fatal accidents that are being investigated by government regulators. [C18.]

United Cancels 200 More Flights United Airlines canceled more than 200 flights nationwide, disrupting service for thousands of passengers for the fourth consecutive day. The cancellations come after a disastrous weekend in which United, the world's largest airline, was racked by delays and forced to cancel about 600 flights, or about 15 percent of its weekend service. [C18.]

FirstEnergy Agrees to Acquire GPU FirstEnergy, an Ohio-based utility company, agreed to acquire GPU of Morristown, N.J., for $4.5 billion in cash and stock. The acquisition would make FirstEnergy the sixth-largest energy concern in the United States, based on customers served. Its increased size and scale would also give it the potential to produce and distribute electricity more efficiently, industry analysts said. [C6.]

Pataki Signs Con Edison Measure Gov. George E. Pataki, putting the blame for a February nuclear accident squarely on Consolidated Edison, signed a bill forcing the company to repay customers more than $100 million it has collected in expenses from the accident and prohibiting it from collecting tens of millions more. Con Edison promised to sue the state to void the law. [A1.]

Dow Rises 109 Points; Nasdaq Falls Blue-chip stocks moved higher as tame inflation data lured investors back to interest rate-sensitive shares. The Dow rose 109.88 points, or 1 percent, to 10,976.89. The Standard & Poor's 500-stock index was up 3.48 points, or 0.2 percent, to 1,482.80. The Nasdaq shed 14.44 points, or 0.4 percent, to 3,848.55. [C7.]

Hyundai Profit Spurs Call for Spinoff The Hyundai Group, South Korea's largest conglomerate, reported record profits in its automotive business, an unexpected piece of good news from a company known more lately for its heavy debts. Hyundai creditors seized on the news to demand that the parent company hasten its promised restructuring and separate the auto business from Hyundai's unhealthy subsidiaries. [C3.]

Top Two Executives Resign at Dial Dial, the maker of Dial soap and Armour canned meats, warning that it would miss earnings expectations for the third time this year, announced that its two top executives had resigned. [C4.]

Reality on the Yellow Brick Road Warner LeRoy grew up on the back lot of the Warner Brothers studio and was on all the movie sets, most memorably the day a scene was being filmed from ''The Wizard of Oz.'' He tells that story and others as he traces his life from Hollywood to boarding school in Switzerland with a roommate who is now the Aga Khan, to drama classes at Stanford, and to milestones in the theater, restaurant and amusement park industries in New York and vicinity. The Boss. [C5.]

Poor Face Choices on Energy Costs Millions of low-income Americans remain untouched by the flourishing economy and, as a result, unprotected from the effects of rising fuel and utility prices. Those prices inflict painful choices -- especially in cities without adequate public transportation and in small towns and suburbs where long distances make driving a necessity. [A14.]
